content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun clash, great test cases! It took me 10 minutes because I didn't bother to read the statement properly but the difficulty level is perfect for a clash.

Reading the problem statement from top to bottom, it is still a bit confusing when you get to the example and you see "start", the ">" and "<" signs, and the column of numbers without much explanation.  

Something to this effect may make it clearer:
===
An old safe has a dial lock with numbers 0 to 89.  The dial may be turned in either direction.  Being that is an old safe, it will open if the final value on which the dial stops is within 3 numbers of the KEY in either direction.

Your task is to determine: (1) if the safe opens or not; and (2) the final value on the dial.

You will be provided with a COMBINATION (maybe START value and sequence of TURNS is clearer?) which you must follow to determine whether the safe can be opened.  The COMBINATION is made up of a start value for the dial followed by a series of turns.  Each turn is comprised of:  (1) a ">" (indicating turn right) or "<" (turn left) sign;  and (2) an integer value telling you how far to turn in that direction.

For example, for the combination: 

0>80<50>100<5>14<20

the dial starts at 0, then the following turns occur:

>80 --> turn right 80, leaving the dial pointing at 80
<50 --> turn left 50, leaving the dial pointing at 30
>100 --> turn right 100, leaving the dial pointing at 40
<5 --> turn left 5, leaving the dial at 35
>14 --> turn right 14, leaving the dial at 49
<20 --> turn left 20, leaving the dial at 29

Since the final reading on the dial is 29, which is within 3 of 30, the safe can be opened.  

Your output should be:
OPEN
29
===

Two other points more generally about the problem:

(1) In a conventional lock where the numbers are on the dial, if you turn clockwise/right, the numbers actually go backwards (and vice versa for counter clockwise/left).  Unless you mean the pointer is what spins and the numbers do not spin but are stationary on the safe...

(2) It is a little unexpected to have only one number in the combination and not 3 numbers in the combination as was mentioned below.  The typical 3 "key" combination master lock requiring x turns to the right, y turns to the left, z turns to the right landing within 3 of each key would make the problem harder and more realistic.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: its fun and iteresting.

Shouldn't a safe's combination need to hit (within 3 of) 3 different numbers in order to open?
As it stands, this puzzle is just "replace > with + and < with -".

This puzzle is fine, but the statement was very difficult to understand for me, it take me longer to understand it than do the code.
The statement is quite long and key points are scattered all along the text,   inputs explanations about the combinations are very clear but I was confused because of the statement, it takes me a lot a time to link both. (I think it's because of my bad English but I may not the alone in that case).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun and unique puzzle to solve.
I think there will be many different solutions for this puzzle.
Just make sure to have test edge-cases
My solution: https://pastebin.com/9mNzhfPT

Interesting puzzle.
It seems to me your solution would not work for test cases where for instance 1 is the key and 89 is the number you stop at. Since the dial is round the "distance" is in fact less than 3 but using  a simple abs would not take that into account. Unless we are not supposed to compute the distance on the dial but then I think the statement "within 3 numbers or closer in either direction to the KEY." could be misinterpreted.  But maybe that's just because I'm not a native speaker.
Good point! I'll add another test case to ensure this is tested and make a code amendment.

Nice solution!
Hoping the edge cases included are sufficient as they do test the overlaps which is main concerns.
Thanks for feedback. I'll add clockwise = > (+) and anti-clockwise = < (-) if that helps?

It's not easy to say now I've solved it, but I would have liked to see something like :
Step: Operating the dial                                                :New dial value
0    :Start   Value                                                                : 0    
>80  :turn the dial counter clockwise by =  (+)80   : 80   
<50  :turn the dial clockwise by =                    (-)50   : 30   
>100 :turn the dial counter clockwise by =  (+)100  : 40   
<5   :turn the dial clockwise by =                       (-)5    : 35   
>14  :turn the dial counter clockwise by =    (+)14   : 49   
<20  :turn the dial clockwise by =                     (-)20   : 29

29, so the safe will OPEN
Output:
OPEN
29

Note: I wanted to write it like a table, but I don't how set fixed size chars here.

I didn't really want to give away the easy way to solve it with the + / - substitution in languages like Python. 
I will lay out the combination moves to be easier, reluctant to add the + / -
